Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Status page - markdown transform sometimes yields garbage" (#6300) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Sometimes [`Markdown` generates garbage (e.g. repetitious and incorrect HTML) when we call `Transform`](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Status/blob/master/src/NuGet.Status/Extensions/MessageExtensions.cs).

Restarting the service has been shown to fix the issue.

`Markdown` may not be thread-safe, or it may start to have issues over time.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Status job - listen to average of all index lag instead of max for package publishing alerts" (#6299) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Closed pull request "Paginate packages for profile page in database" (#6139) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
For #5877 and #5659 

Deploying the current dev code into an Azure App Service in the production slot, and putting my changes in a staging slot, then hitting page 2 on both sites 120 times each, App Insights tells me these results:

Version | 50th percentile | 95th percentile
---- | ----- | -----
dev code | 5,027ms | 6,150ms
these changes | 3,674ms | 4,570ms

The contents appear to be the same, except that the total package download count is different. It might be due to bad data in my database (I manually set the TotalDownloads column in the PackageRegistrations table, but didn't change the Packages table). However, I think that the value after my changes appear to be more correct than before my changes, so I'm not sure if this fixes a total downloads count bug.

The SQL that the various queries execute are horrific, but I guess that's part of using an ORM, and the performance is still better than paginating in C#. I have not tried any optimisation, I just re-used the existing query.

When shown during nuget.exe push, this is actually too late since the package is already pushed. We can warn sooner on the registered certificates UI.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Unify logging and telemetry abstractions in the gallery" (#6296) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
@joelverhagen commented on [Thu Jul 26 2018](https://github.com/NuGet/Engineering/issues/1570)

Today, gallery has multiple logging abstractions.

- `IDiagnosticsSource.TraceEvent`
- `IDiagnosticsSource.ExceptionEvent`
- `IDiagnosticsSource.Log` (from `ILogger` which `IDiagnosticsSource` implements)
- `QuietLog`

Also, multiple telemetry abstractions:

- `ITelemetryService`
- `IDiagnosticsSource.PerfEvent`

These should be consolidated and align with the practices of other repos. Namely, use `ILogger` for logging of trace messages and exceptions and use the `ITelemetryService` for metrics and events.

---

@joelverhagen commented on [Thu Jul 26 2018](https://github.com/NuGet/Engineering/issues/1570#issuecomment-408271317)

/cc @chenriksson

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Integrate status page with status JSON" (#6115) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Closed issue "Unhelpful error message when incorrectly using nuspec version tag of nuget pack" (#2714) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
I was just trying to use:

`nuget pack file.nuspec`

I was stuck for a while because of the error message:

`Value cannot be null or an empty string.
Parameter name: value`

Turns out this is because I was using `<version>$version$</version>` in my nuspec, but not explicitly passing the package version. That makes sense, but I struggled to track this down - would it be possible to improve the error message here, and perhaps at least point the user towards the part of the nuspec file causing the issue.

Thanks!

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Update-Package modifies PackageReference version " (#7193) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
HI,

My VS version is 2017. I see there is PackageReference in this version of VS. 

Here is the issue I observed.

I created sample UWPEmpty project. 

1. Added my nuget package UWPClass with version 1.1.2345.2346. 
    Observed my project file got new entry as below
           <PackageReference Include="UWPClass" Version="1.1.2345.2346" />.
2. To control updates, I updated Version no to Version="(1.0,2.0)". 
3. I got new update for my package (Version 1.1.2350.2347)
4. I updated my package. 
In my project file
Expected: Version No should remain "(1.0,2.0)" 
Actual: Version="1.1.2350.2347"

Details: Purpose of wild card version control is defeated if package update modifies my version def

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "API can deadlock when called from synchronous code. Should be using ConfigureAwait(false)." (#7192) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem

The nuget API uses async/await extensively, but doesn't seem to use ConfigureAwait(false). This means synchronous APIs have to go out of their way to avoid deadlocks by calling your code like this:


`                            // Search on the thread pool to avoid deadlocks
                            var publishedPackages = Task.Run(async () =>
                                {
                                    return await (await customRepository
                                            .GetResourceAsync<PackageSearchResource>(cancellationTokenSource.Token)
                                            .ConfigureAwait(false))
                                        .SearchAsync("AudioWorks.Extensions",
                                            new SearchFilter(true), 0, 100, NullLogger.Instance,
                                            cancellationTokenSource.Token)
                                        .ConfigureAwait(false);
                                }).Result`

It would be super cool if you could add some .ConfigureAwait(false) calls wherever await is used.
 I don't believe there are any drawbacks.
